itemdesc-stone-obsidian: Can be thrown or knapped into stone tools and weapons.
itemdesc-shears-*: Very handy for cutting tree leaves
itemdesc-prospectingpick-*: Detects Deposits that are above 2.5% concentration level. Does not register surface copper, quartz, rock salt or lapis lazuli
itemdesc-longblade-admin: With great power comes great responsibility.
itemdesc-longblade-*: A sword to fend off your enemies.
itemdesc-lore-*: A story passed down for others to read.
handbooktext-wattle:
Keeps animals in (or out ...). Not so good against the rain or the cold!

Allows some light to pass through.
Pit kilns need to be surrounded by solid: Pit kilns need to be surrounded by solid, non-flammable blocks
Pit kilns need one block of air space ab: Pit kilns need one block of air space above them
blockdesc-tallplant-coopersreed-*-normal: Harvest with a knife to keep roots intact
blockdesc-tallplant-papyrus-*-normal-*: Harvest with a knife to keep roots intact
block-handbooktext-crucible-*: The crucible is used to melt down metal bits and nuggets, to then be poured into molds. Large metal parts first need to be broken down to bits to fit inside.
itemdesc-sewingkit: Used for repairs and making new clothes
blockdesc-oreblastingbomb: This bomb is particularly effective for mining ores, but less so for plain rock blasting. Has a 10% chance of destroying ores and a very high chance of destroying crystals and crystalized ores.
blockdesc-mushroom-*:
Mushroom
Use knife to harvest quicker
block-handbooktext-soil-high-*: Terra Preta is found as deposits within low or medium fertility soils, in areas with correct rainfall and temperature.  It will not spawn at high elevations, areas of very low temperature, or areas of low rainfall.
block-handbooktext-rock-halite:
'Salt domes' of halite can potentially be found in any area with at least one sedimentary stone layer, no matter the climate. The thicker the sedimentary layers, the better the chance.
Additionally, halite can be found as 'dry lake bed' deposits in deserts in hot, tropical climates, just underneath the sand and gravel top layers.
blockdesc-woodencrate-*: Old pre 1.16 crate. Please place and break to upgrade it to the new crate version
block-handbooktext-crate: Place in the crafting grid to open or close the crate. Combine with a parchment to be able to draw the crates current contents, use any pigment item to draw, for example charcoal.
blockdesc-door-log-*: Crudely made, tends to fall apart when used
block-handbooktext-torch-up: In addition to illuminating the environment, a torch can be used to light a firepit or charcoal pit, re-light an extinguished torch, and ignite many other things such as bloomery.
block-handbooktext-leaves-*: leaf blocks have a smaller chance to drop sticks and seeds than branchy leaf blocks. The chance is unaffected by tool used to harvest them. Unlike branchy leaf blocks, regular leaves will notcount against axe durability when cutting down a tree.
block-handbooktext-leavesbranchy-*: Branchy leaves are guaranteed to drop a stick. They also have a higher chance to drop seeds. The chance is unaffected by tool used to harvest them. Unlike normal leaf blocks, branchy leaves willcount against axe durability when cutting down a tree, if still connected to the trunk.
block-handbooktext-log-resin-pine-ud: Resinous logs only generate in trees created at world generation. Never in trees that are grown from saplings. Such logs are not common, and only a small percentage of pines will have one.
blockdesc-creativelight-*: Creative mode block. Glows and emits lots of light.
blockdesc-creativeglow-*: Creative mode block. Glows and emits little light.
itemdesc-lootrandomizer: Can be used for randomized dungeon loot. Right click to add random loot. When placed in a container (e.g. chest), then exported and imported via worldedit/worldgen this item will turn into one random item as configured.
itemcraftdesc-arrowhead-*: Arrows are great for ranged combat once you acquired a bow
itemcraftdesc-axehead-*: For basic close range defense and tree chopping
itemcraftdesc-knifeblade-*: For basic close range defense and gathering of plant matter
itemcraftdesc-spearhead-*: Convenient long range defense, but breaks quite quickly
itemcraftdesc-shovelhead-*: Helps you break soil blocks a little quicker
itemcraftdesc-hammerhead-*: Hammers are required to work ingots on the anvil
itemcraftdesc-padlock-*: Lets you lock doors and chests
itemcraftdesc-prospectingpickhead-*: Prospecting picks let you probe the ground on the search for areas rich in ore
itemcraftdesc-sawblade-*: Will allow you to craft planks
itemcraftdesc-shears-*: Greatly speeds up breaking of tree leaves to get more sticks and saplings
itemcraftdesc-cleaver-*: Reliably 1-hit kills animals after their 3rd bred generation
itemcraftdesc-scythehead-*: Greatly speeds up harvesting of grass and crops
itemdesc-gear-rusty: Despite its corroded state, it still shows exceptional quality and craftsmanship. The fine details seem impossible to reproduce. Probably why the traders favor it so much.
itemdesc-gear-temporal: Shivering, yet somehow sturdy. Can be shattered to create a 'returning point'.
itemdesc-backpack: Increases the amount of items you can carry
itemdesc-basket: Increases the amount of items you can carry
itemdesc-linensack: Increases the amount of items you can carry
item-handbooktext-grain-*: Use a quern to grind grains into flour
itemdesc-rawcassava-raw: Soak in water to make this edible
itemdesc-rawcassava-soaked: Now peel this with a knife to make it edible
item-handbooktext-cassava:
Cassava is a useful vegetable, it can be added as a starchy vegetable to meals, or dried and ground to make flour. The Cassava plant tolerates most warm climates and yields a good quantity of the crop.

Raw cassava is toxic, however. To make it safe to eat, it must first be soaked in water for a day (hint: use a barrel). The Soaked cassava must be peeled with a knife. Cassava can then be added to meals as a vegetable. Once peeled, it must be used within a few hours or else it will start to dry out. When dried its only use is to be ground to make Cassava flour.
itemdesc-clay-*: Can be formed into basic pottery items. Sneak + Right mouse click on the ground to begin clay forming.
item-handbooktext-clay-*: Clay deposits are found in any area with high enough preciptation (so not deserts) and high enough temperature (so not the arctic).  They can be found at any elevation.  You may notice them on the map as semi-ciruclar spots of a slightly different color from surrounding grass.
item-handbooktext-clearquartz: Smelting quartz requires temperatures too high for regular fuels. Use a bloomery to smelt quartz into glass.
itemdesc-flaxfibers: 4 of them can be turned into twine
itemdesc-flint: Can be knapped into slightly better stone tools and weapons. Sneak + Right mouse click on the ground to begin knapping.
item-handbooktext-ore-lapislazuli: Items that are a pigment can be used to write on signs, and sometimes also to dye cloth.
item-handbooktext-ore-quartz: Smelting quartz requires temperatures too high for regular fuels. Use a bloomery to smelt quartz into glass.
itemdesc-powderedsulfur: Used for bombs and bandages. Smells bad.
itemdesc-saltpeter:
Time to make some bombs!

...or a fertile garden!
itemdesc-ore-diamond: Looks like a piece of colored glass? I wonder what is it good for.
itemdesc-ore-emerald: Looks like a piece of colored glass? I wonder what is it good for.
itemdesc-seeds-pumpkin: When planting, make sure to leave a lot of extra space around it
item-handbooktext-stick: Sticks have a chance to drop from normal leaf blocks, and are guaranteed to drop from branchy leaves. You can also find them laying on the ground in forests. If you fell an entire tree with an axe, leaves will also break, however, you'll get far fewer sticks than if you had broken the leaf blocks individually first. The drop chance from breaking leaf blocks is not affected by the type of tool used to break the block: but you can use shears to harvest sticks swiftly.
item-handbooktext-shears-*: Shears will break all leaf (and branchy leaf) blocks in a 3x3x3 cube centered on the block they are used on. Thus they can be used to harvest sticks, and potentially tree seeds, very fast.
itemdesc-longblade-blackguard: Short and lightweight. Made for skirmishes in the narrow tunnels.
itemdesc-longblade-forlorn: An elegant blade; it was of little use against what was coming for them.
block-handbooktext-torch-extinct-up: When placed, an extinguished torch can be relit using a firestarter or a torch.
handbook-charcoal-drawing:
Charcoal can be used to write labels on chests: shift right-click on the label to write.

Charcoal can be used to draw symbols and cave paintings on hard surfaces. While aiming at a hard surface, use 'F' key (Tool Mode) to change symbol. Right-click to draw. (Chalk, hematite and limonite can also be used for different color effects.)
handbook-chalk-drawing:
Chalk can be used to write labels on chests: shift right-click on the label to write.

Chalk can be used to draw symbols and cave paintings on hard surfaces. While aiming at a hard surface, use 'F' key (Tool Mode) to change symbol. Right-click to draw. (Charcoal, hematite and limonite can also be used for different color effects.)
handbook-limonite-drawing: Rich pieces of Limonite can be used to draw symbols and cave paintings on hard surfaces.  While aiming at a hard surface, use 'F' key (Tool Mode) to change symbol.  Right-click to draw.  (Charcoal, chalk and hematite can also be used for different color effects.)
handbook-hematite-drawing: Rich pieces of Hematite can be used to draw symbols and cave paintings on hard surfaces.  While aiming at a hard surface, use 'F' key (Tool Mode) to change symbol.  Right-click to draw.  (Charcoal, chalk and limonite can also be used for different color effects.)
item-handbooktext-creature-chicken-*:
Chickens are fed using a small trough, and will lay eggs in a hen box (or on the ground if no henbox is available). Chickens must be well fed to lay. Chickens must also be well fed to sit in the henbox for long enough to hatch the eggs.

A rooster is necessary, for fertile eggs.
blockdesc-quern-*: A millstone for grinding soft stones and grains.
block-handbooktext-skep-empty-*:
A skep can be placed near a wild bee hive, or near an already populated skep, to attract a new colony of bees to populate it. This will require some nearby flowers as well. When a skep is full, you can destroy it to harvest the honey, but this will destroy that colony of bees (they may also become angry!).

Bees do not produce honey in very cold weather.
itemdesc-honeycomb: Squeeze out over a bucket or bowl to get honey and wax
block-wildbeehive-inlog-baldcypress: Wild beehive in bald cypress tree
itemdesc-beenade-closed:
Stingy fun for the whole family!
0.5 blunt damage when thrown. Spawns an angry mob of bees upon impact.
item-handbooktext-beenade-closed: Beenades contain only worker bees, so they cannot be used to populate a skep

itemdesc-clothes-foot-fur-boots: Given time, and the Falxian creations, travelers from very distant lands began to appear across the kingdoms. Amongst their number were those who dwelt in the far north.
itemdesc-clothes-face-hunter-mask: Provides what little protection it can against the sickness.
itemdesc-clothes-face-malefactor-mask: Any discoloration on the mask would be deemed too dangerous to allow re-entry. Those who were brave enough to make multiple journeys would carve tallies on their masks, to show how many times they had cheated death.
itemdesc-clothes-face-tailor-mask: Provides a touch of security when dealing with customers.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-fur-gloves: Given time, and the Falxian creations, travelers from very distant lands began to appear across the kingdoms. Amongst their number were those who dwelt in the far north.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-fur-coat: Given time, and the Falxian creations, travelers from very distant lands began to appear across the kingdoms. Amongst their number were those who dwelt in the far north.
blockdesc-torchholder-aged-empty-*: Can be used to place torches inside, which will never burn out
item-resonancearchive-2: Resonance archive (Through The Grass at Night)
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-anvil: A bakeable mold to create an anvil, which is required for more advanced tools
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-helvehammer: One part required to create a helve hammer for mechanized smithing
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-axe: To create axe heads directly from molten metal
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-hammer: To create hammer heads directly from molten metal
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-shovel: To create shovel heads directly from molten metal
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-longblade: To create longblade heads directly from molten metal
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-hoe: To create hoe heads directly from molten metal
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-pickaxe: To create pickaxe heads directly from molten metal
blockcraftdesc-toolmold-raw-prospectingp: To create prospecting pick heads directly from molten metal
blockcraftdesc-bowl-raw: Bowls can be used to eat from cooking pots, combined with fat for permanent light sources, and other uses
blockcraftdesc-storagevessel-raw: 12 Slot container, good for preserving grains and vegetables
blockcraftdesc-crucible-raw: To smelt ores on the firepit
blockcraftdesc-crock-raw-east: To preserve meals and pickled foods
blockcraftdesc-ingotmold-raw: To cast metal ingots for storage or later use on the anvil
blockcraftdesc-claypot-raw: A large pot that can be used for cooking (see meal making guide in the handbook)
blockcraftdesc-wateringcan-raw: Allows you to water farm land thats without nearby water source blocks as well as put out fire
blockcraftdesc-clayoven-north: For cooking baked goods.  You will need a quern before you can make use of a clay oven.
itemdesc-clothes-arm-squire-bracers: Such clothes are cast aside for more protective accoutrements upon achieving knighthood.
itemdesc-clothes-arm-prisoner-binds: A Rot of human design. For what could be worse than the slow, silent decay of sinew and spirit?
itemdesc-clothes-arm-merchant-bracelet: The Hanseatic League, with their merchant navies, offered their services to charter and transport the incredible amount of goods, materials, and refugees. It was a monumental effort of logistics; something only they could pull off.
itemdesc-clothes-arm-copper-bracelet: This belonged to clan chieftain of the Celtic isles. A burden of leadership and protection.
itemdesc-clothes-arm-tailor-needlepuff: All those clothes — torn to pieces and left in the dark. But not forgotten.
itemdesc-clothes-emblem-squire-emblem: They were young lads, often noble-born. This was a symbol of their fledgling honor.
itemdesc-clothes-emblem-royal-pin: Proof of his bloodline. He wore it proudly as the light faded around him.
itemdesc-clothes-emblem-blackguard-pin: They resolved to do whatever they must to survive. This was a sign of their dread conviction.
itemdesc-clothes-emblem-malefactor-penda: Those who committed crimes in the underground were exiled to join the scouts on the surface until they found something of value to bring back.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-temptress-velvet-s: A countess, a diplomat, a mystery. She moved freely from court to court, sowing intrigue for some grand purpose. Truth be told, I don't think anyone could have stopped her.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-nomad-boots: This was worn by Akmal, the poet. Ever curious, he roamed the countryside, seeking wisdom.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-squire-boots: Such clothes are cast aside for more protective accoutrements upon achieving knighthood.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-shepherd-sandals: Simple shepherd’s clothing. They could be found caring for and protecting their flock. Not anymore.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-prisoner-binds: A Rot of human design. For what could be worse than the slow, silent decay of sinew and spirit?
itemdesc-clothes-foot-prince-boots: The ceremonial garb of Prince Wilfried. The proud, last-remaining Imperial son.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-peasent-slippers: From a time when men were corralled by other men, not by monsters.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-noble-shoes: The Stadtholder’s garb. He was a vain man.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-minstrel-boots: The costume of the famous trobairitz Azalais.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-messenger-shoes: They carried a simple message, and they were hated and feared for it.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-merchant-shoes: The Hanseatic League, with their merchant navies, offered their services to charter and transport the incredible amount of goods, materials, and refugees. It was a monumental effort of logistics; something only they could pull off.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-lackey-shoes: Loyal attendants. They clung to kings and queens as a way of life. Graceful or foolish — it was hard to say.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-fur-lined-reindeer: The colorful wear of a Sámi. They fared well in their frozen lands. Truly, we envied them.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-great-steppe-boots: The common folk adored them for their exploits and humility.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-aristocrat-shoes: Despite his efforts, the nobility flourished during those golden years.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-blackguard-shoes: They maintained order while the world collapsed around them.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-clockmaker-shoes: Simple shoes cobbled together for life in a city.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-malefactor-boots: Improvised to travel through the filth and mire.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-forlorn-shoes: The last vassals of a dwindling era.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-commoner-boots: Still strong, despite years of damage.
itemdesc-clothes-foot-tailor-shoes: Protection and style, the tailor's produce.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-prince-gloves: The ceremonial garb of Prince Wilfried. The proud, last-remaining Imperial son.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-noble-riding-glove: The Stadtholder’s garb. He was a vain man.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-minstrel-gloves: The costume of the famous trobairitz Azalais.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-lackey-gloves: Loyal attendants. They clung to kings and queens as a way of life. Graceful or foolish — it was hard to say.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-hunter-gloves: Made to endure the bowstring's affections.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-malefactor-gloves: Heavy wrappings meant to be discarded after prolonged use.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-forlorn-bracer: The right hand kept loose, they were quick to challenge any slight against the faith.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-commoner-gloves: Protective, yet supple. Good for a variety of tasks.
itemdesc-clothes-hand-tailor-gloves: Long hours inevitably led to injury.
itemdesc-clothes-head-squire-hood: Such clothes are cast aside for more protective accoutrements upon achieving knighthood.
itemdesc-clothes-head-snow-goggles: From what I gathered, the Northerners carried these goggles to protect themselves from the overwhelming light of their home. This style was eventually picked up by some machinists who found it invaluable.
itemdesc-clothes-head-silver-diadem: Brave and pure, Wilfried remained behind on the surface with a small regiment. He was tasked to hold back any desperate, violent beings seeking entry to the underground.
itemdesc-clothes-head-shepherds-cowl: Simple shepherd’s clothing. They could be found caring for and protecting their flock. Not anymore.
itemdesc-clothes-head-noble-fillet: For all his fanfare, he was surprisingly moderate in policy.
itemdesc-clothes-head-minstrel-hat: The costume of the famous trobairitz Azalais.
itemdesc-clothes-head-messengers-hat: The message eventually reached every village, every town. At least the ones that were left.
itemdesc-clothes-head-merchant-hat: When the time came to retreat underground, the Hansa refused. They dropped off the last of their cargo, then lifted their ramps and set sail into an increasingly dark sea.
itemdesc-clothes-head-lackey-hat: Loyal attendants. They clung to kings and queens as a way of life. Graceful or foolish — it was hard to say.
itemdesc-clothes-head-jailors-hat: Innovation did not always herald a change in polity. In this, we were the same as ever.
itemdesc-clothes-head-gold-coronet: Vestments of the old royalty, who refused the Oath and clung to their lands. Hail to the lords of rubble.
itemdesc-clothes-head-fortune-tellers-sc: He believed there was truth in the words of the old crones and wanderers. A truth only he could see.
itemdesc-clothes-head-hunter-cape: Excessively washed and repaired multiple times.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-tattered-peas: From a time when men were corralled by other men, not by monsters.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-nomad-trouser: This was worn by Akmal, the poet. Ever curious, he roamed the countryside, seeking wisdom.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-squire-pants: Such clothes are cast aside for more protective accoutrements upon achieving knighthood.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-shepherd-pant: Simple shepherd’s clothing. They could be found caring for and protecting their flock. Not anymore.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-raw-hide-trou: Rather unrefined, but warm and protective.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-reindeer-herd: The colorful wear of a Sámi. They fared well in their frozen lands. Truly, we envied them.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-prince-breech: The ceremonial garb of Prince Wilfried. The proud, last-remaining Imperial son.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-noble-pants: The Stadtholder’s garb. He was a vain man.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-minstrel-pant: The costume of the famous trobairitz Azalais.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-messenger-tro: They carried a simple message, and they were hated and feared for it.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-merchant-pant: The Hanseatic League, with their merchant navies, offered their services to charter and transport the incredible amount of goods, materials, and refugees. It was a monumental effort of logistics; something only they could pull off.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-lackey-breech: Loyal attendants. They clung to kings and queens as a way of life. Graceful or foolish — it was hard to say.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-jailor-pants: Innovation did not always herald a change in polity. In this, we were the same as ever.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-aristocrat-le: Despite his efforts, the nobility flourished during those golden years.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-blackguard-le: They relied only on each other, using whatever means they had to ensure progress in those dark tunnels.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-clockmaker-pa: Stained here and there with oil and lacquer.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-hunter-leggin: Speckled in lingering mud stains. Remnants of the marshlands.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-malefactor-tr: Some people adapted poorly to the underground. They longed to see the forests again.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-forlorn-pants: The knights put their faith in the blessed device to deliver them from imminent death.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-commoner-trou: Humble clothing. For some, it was all they had.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-tailor-trouse: Even a tailor runs out of cloth from time to time.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-homespun-pant: Simple garb to keep you warm.
itemdesc-clothes-lowerbody-pastoral-pant: Made for warm days and cold nights.
itemdesc-clothes-neck-noble-necklace: The Stadtholder’s garb. He was a vain man.
itemdesc-clothes-neck-merchant-amulet: They chose a different struggle. Who knows if any of them survived?
itemdesc-clothes-neck-fancy-royal-collar: One day a strange man came to the gate, claiming to be a lost king. He wore only this gaudy collar and a belt.
itemdesc-clothes-neck-copper-torc: This belonged to a clan chieftain of the Celtic isles. A burden of leadership and protection.
itemdesc-clothes-neck-forlorn-talisman: They sought to enwreathe themselves in the prima materia and wield it directly. Much of their efforts were directed towards such a feat.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-royal-fur: The ceremonial garb of Prince Wilfried. The proud, last-remaining Imperial son.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-peasent-kaftan: From a time when men were corralled by other men, not by monsters.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-noble-fur-coll: The Stadtholder’s garb. He was a vain man.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-minstrel-coat: The costume of the famous trobairitz Azalais.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-hunter-poncho: A humble shelter from the wind and rain.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-aristocrat-man: Despite his efforts, the nobility flourished during those golden years.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-squire-tunic: Such clothes are cast aside for more protective accoutrements upon achieving knighthood.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-clockmaker-apr: A small inscription on the backside reads “Tempus Rerum Imperator”
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-forlorn-sash: The Order of the Forlorn Hope: like-minded knights brought together by desperation and curiosity.
itemdesc-clothes-shoulder-malefactor-clo: A thick leather cloak to protect against exposure.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-nomad-man: Some time later, he confessed that he was an agent of the Khanate. By that point, it was of no concern.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-reindeer-: The colorful wear of a Sámi. They fared well in their frozen lands. Truly, we envied them.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-cerise-em: The colorful wear of a Sámi. Warm and comfortable.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-great-ste: She was a falconer, from beyond the mountains. With bow and talons, they made a name for themselves.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-clockmake: Horology lent itself well to the new inventions, thus clockmakers found themselves in high demand.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-hunter-co: Warm and obscuring, for one who traveled overland during the last hunts.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-malefacto: Vagabonds, foragers, and thieves; the outcasts would venture to the surface in search of any remaining resources.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-commoner-: When faced with overwhelming despair, some refugees found a powerful will to survive.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbodyover-tailor-ja: Colors, styles, fittings... something wondrous for each customer.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-great-steppe-: Her partner, Lima, was always close by, circling the skies.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-raw-hide-mant: Rather unrefined, but warm and protective.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-temptress-vel: A countess, a diplomat, a mystery. She moved freely from court to court, sowing intrigue for some grand purpose. Truth be told, I don't think anyone could have stopped her.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-squire-shirt: Such clothes are cast aside for more protective accoutrements upon achieving knighthood.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-shepherd-tuni: Simple shepherd’s clothing. They could be found caring for and protecting their flock. Not anymore.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-reindeer-herd: The colorful wear of a Sámi. They fared well in their frozen lands. Truly, we envied them.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-prince-tunic: The ceremonial garb of Prince Wilfried. The proud, last-remaining Imperial son.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-peasent-shirt: From a time when men were corralled by other men, not by monsters.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-noble-shirt: The Stadtholder’s garb. He was a vain man.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-minstrel-shir: The costume of the famous trobairitz Azalais.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-messenger-shi: They carried a simple message, and they were hated and feared for it.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-merchant-shir: The Hanseatic League, with their merchant navies, offered their services to charter and transport the incredible amount of goods, materials, and refugees. It was a monumental effort of logistics; something only they could pull off.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-lackey-shirt: Loyal attendants. They clung to kings and queens as a way of life. Graceful or foolish — it was hard to say.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-jailor-tunic: Innovation did not always herald a change in polity. In this, we were the same as ever.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-hunter-shirt: Hunters across the land were called upon to put their talents to use and to bring mercy to their old quarries.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-aristocrat-sh: Despite his efforts, the nobility flourished during those golden years.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-blackguard-sh: A new company was formed. This one cared not for liege nor coin nor faith.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-clockmaker-sh: Unassuming wear. The garb of a craftsman suddenly elevated to an important role.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-forlorn-tunic: Imbued with alchemical symbols. They were both scholars and warriors.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-commoner-shir: Some people, despite their lack of expertise, found ways to contribute. They were some of our most resilient.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-tailor-blouse: Artisans provided what assistance they could and plied their craft when able.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-homespun-shir: Simple garb to keep you warm.
itemdesc-clothes-upperbody-pastoral-shir: Made for warm days and cold nights.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-squire-belt: Such clothes are cast aside for more protective accoutrements upon achieving knighthood.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-reindeer-herder-w: The colorful wear of a Sámi. They fared well in their frozen lands. Truly, we envied them.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-prince-waistband: The ceremonial garb of Prince Wilfried. The proud, last-remaining Imperial son.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-peasant-strap: From a time when men were corralled by other men, not by monsters.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-noble-sash: The Stadtholder’s garb. He was a vain man.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-messenger-belt: They carried a simple message, and they were hated and feared for it.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-merchant-belt: The Hanseatic League, with their merchant navies, offered their services to charter and transport the incredible amount of goods, materials, and refugees. It was a monumental effort of logistics; something only they could pull off.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-jailor-belt: Cruel devices. Pained cries. Ever our shame.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-fortune-teller-hi: He believed there was truth in the words of the old crones and wanderers. A truth only he could see.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-fancy-royal-belt: One day a strange man came to the gate, claiming to be a lost king. He wore only this gaudy belt and a collar.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-cerise-embroidere: The colorful wear of a Sámi. Warm and comfortable.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-aristocrat-belt: Despite his efforts, the nobility flourished during those golden years.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-blackguard-belt: In those days a certain discipline and practicality took hold of many soldiers.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-clockmaker-belt: Small precision tools. Caliper, file, ball-peen hammer.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-malefactor-sash: Some outcasts liked to keep a few findings for themselves.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-forlorn-belt: Fastened with charms and trinkets to guide them.
itemdesc-clothes-waist-tailor-belt: Tools of the trade ready to sever or sew as needed.
blockdesc-wateringcan-burned: To water plants and take out fires
itemdesc-bushmeat-raw: Less nutritious than other meats and tough to chew. Not suitable for meals.
item-handbooktext-egg-chicken-raw: See the Meal making guide for suggested recipes.
mainmenu-greeting: Welcome, fellow player! Thank you for trying out the early access version of Vintage Story. If you would like to share anything with us, we cordially invite you to our forums and discord chat. Our ears are always open for issues and suggestions. If you encounter any problems, please do report them on our issue tracker We are working tirelessly on improving the game and we would love to have you by our side in this journey :-) Either way, we sincerely hope this game will bring you joy! - the Vintage Story Team
singleplayer-disabledcustomizations: Some settings disabled, as they can not be changed in existing worlds.
playstyle-surviveandbuild-patchy: Survive and Build with patchy climate
playstyle-surviveandbuild-bands: Survive and Build with realistic climate
playstyle-desc-surviveandbuild-patchy:
Pretty Terrain, Patchy Climate

Permanent light sources (oil lamps, lanterns), health recovery through eating, hunger bar, slow block breaking, normal monsters and normal difficulty
playstyle-desc-surviveandbuild-bands:
Pretty Terrain, Realistic Climate

Permanent light sources (oil lamps, lanterns), health recovery through eating, hunger bar, slow block breaking, normal monsters and normal difficulty
playstyle-desc-preset-surviveandbuild: The default survival experience of Vintage Story. Balanced exploration, building and survival.
playstyle-desc-preset-exploration: For players that do not enjoy combat or a significant focus on survival. Greater focus on exploration and building, less focus on survival.
playstyle-desc-preset-wildernesssurvival: For players that enjoy challenging combat and survival mechanics. Greater focus on survival, less focus on exploration and building. Respawn randomly within 5000 blocks upon death.
playstyle-desc-creativebuilding: Flat and empty terrain with unlimited blocks, the ability to fly and world editing tools
tooltip-cheatmode: Whether to allow the use of fly mode, change move speed and game mode switching (survival, creative, spectator)
tooltip-seed: Optional. The seed determines the shape of the world. You can type any combination of letters here. If left empty a random seed will be used.
multiplayer-help: If you want to host a world, start a singleplayer world and click 'Open To LAN'
setting-hover-viewdist: How far you can see. In multiplayer the purple area is not made available by the game server. High view distances come at a high fps cost.
setting-hover-viewdist-singleplayer: How far you can see. High view distances come at a high fps and memory cost.
setting-hover-gamma: The overall gamma of the scene. Higher gamma makes the game brighter. Has no effect on overall performance.
setting-hover-sepia: Changes the overall sepia of the scene. Has no effect on overall performance.
setting-hover-fov: How wide you can see. A wider FoV has medium fps cost.
setting-hover-guiscale: Size of all GUI elements, tweak if your dialogs are too small or too big
setting-hover-maxfps: Limits the game's max FPS, for smoother framerate even if below the maximum possible. If your system is running hot, reducing the max FPS will help. Unlimited setting may use 100% CPU. Max FPS setting has no effect if VSync is set to On Recommendation: Put to either 30, 60 or 75 FPS
setting-hover-resolution: Lets you increase/decrease the pixel resolution. High resolutions yield better quality scenes, but can have a very high fps cost. A low resolution may make your game run a lot faster. Note: Screenshots taken with F12 will not show GUI if the resolution is not 100%
setting-hover-smoothshadows: Produces smooth shadow transitions and block-level ambient occlusion. This should normally be left on. Disabling this might help a bit when placing/removing blocks is not instant. Little to no effect on overall fps.
setting-hover-vsync: Off: No hardware VSync. Framerate controlled by Max FPS setting. May cause scene tearing on some systems. On: Fixes tearing, might cause half fps (e.g. 30 instead of 60) for some frames. (May only be effective when the game is fullscreen.) Please note: Some graphics cards override the VSync setting, which means setting it in-game has no effect. For Nvidia cards, you can turn it on or off in the Nvidia Control Panel On+Sleep: Combines the Max FPS control and hardware VSync. Recommended to set Max FPS slightly higher than your monitor's refresh rate. Might reduce stutter issues with VSync for some players.
setting-hover-fxaa: FXAA smoothens out the edges of the scene. Has notable fps cost.
setting-hover-ssao: SSAO adds ambient occlusion to fine geometry at sub-block level, giving the scene a greater sense of depth. High fps cost.
setting-hover-bloom: Enables/Disables Block Bloom and Ambient Bloom. Has notable fps cost.
setting-hover-abloom: Requires Bloom to be on. Applies a bloom effect to the whole scene. Set to 0 to only have block bloom. The intensity level has no effect on overall performance.
setting-hover-godrays: Toggles the crepuscular rays effect. Has very high fps cost.
setting-hover-particles: Controls the Ambient Particle density level and sets an upper limit for the amount of particles alive at the same time. Medium fps cost.
setting-hover-grasswaves: Toggles whether the grass should wave in the wind. Low fps cost.
setting-hover-foamandshinyeffect: Toggles the reflective surfaces on various blocks, and the foam, ripple and specular reflection effects on water surfaces. Medium fps cost. (If you have freeze issues with some Intel HD or Intel Iris internal graphics on laptops, try turning this off)
setting-hover-dynalight: Maximum number of mobile light sources, notable fps cost when using more than a dozen lights
setting-hover-dynashade: Toggles dynamic shadows quality. Has high fps cost.
setting-hover-bobblehead: Up and Down motion of the camera while walking. Turn this off if you are susceptible to motion sickness
setting-hover-hqanimation: Turn off only if your game is laggy. When off, multiple simultaneous animations on creatures look slightly broken, but improves performance (10-20 FPS on 500 animated creatures)
setting-hover-optimizeram:
Advisable at high view distance settings, but you can disable this if you have plenty of RAM to spare. Tries to keep memory usage low, but may cause mild lag spikes when enabled.
Please restart the game world for this change to take effect.
setting-hover-occlusionculling: Enabling this should give you better fps. Recommended if you have a multicore CPU. It removes hidden parts from the scene to reduce load on the graphics card. If you move and change viewing angle very quickly, eg. moving from underground to above ground in creative flight mode, it may take a moment for a chunk to re-appear.
setting-hover-immersivemousemode: Allows you to keep control of your camera while block dialogs are open, as well as displaying them above where their blocks are in-world. You can hold the ALT key to unlock the mouse cursor.
setting-hover-immersivefpmode:
When enabled, you can see your own body also in the first person camera mode.
<font color="orange">Experimental.</font>
setting-hover-language: Set the language of the whole game.
setting-hover-autochat: Will enable the chat hud whenever a new message appears and fade it out after 15 seconds of inactivity
setting-hover-radeonhdfix: For some players on Radeon HD cards the grass is purple. Activate this setting if this is the case for you
setting-notice-lang-communitycreated: Please note that the translations are community created and may be inaccurate or incomplete. We happily accept contributions.
setting-notice-restart: <font color="#e63939">Please restart the game for changes to take effect.</font>

start-survivalintro: Dear Player, The in-game help system - the Handbook - contains useful info which might be essential to your survival! At any time, you can press H to access the Handbook
start-creativeintro: Dear Player, The in-game help system for Creative building is still a work in progress, please refer to our creative mode starter guide on the wiki. If you need access to the world edit tools, hit `. If that doesn't work, you can also type the command .we into the chat bar or change the key-binding in the settings.

trough-staple-sheep-acceptable-pigs: Staple for sheep, very acceptable to pigs

blockdesc-trough-genericwood-small-*: For feeding small animals with grain (1 per portion)
item-handbooktext-honeyportion: Honey is squeezed from honeycombs into a container.
itemdesc-poultice-*: A bandage to heal minor wounds
item-handbooktext-poultice-*: Poultices are a sort of combination of bandage with other healing components, used to help heal wounds.

mainscreen-quote1: If you only do what is easy, your life will be hard.
mainscreen-quote2: If there is no enemy inside, the enemy outside can do no harm.
mainscreen-quote3: It is hard to fail, but it is worse never to have tried to succeed.
mainscreen-quote4: You will face many defeats in life, but never let yourself be defeated.
mainscreen-quote5: Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts.
mainscreen-quote6: Better to have loved and lost, than never to have loved at all.
mainscreen-quote7: The journey of a thousand miles begins with one step.
mainscreen-quote8: You must be the change you wish to see in the world.
mainscreen-quote9: The best way out is always through.
mainscreen-quote10: Good, better, best. Never let it rest. 'Til your good is better and your better is best.
mainscreen-quote11: The past cannot be changed. The future is yet in your power.
mainscreen-quote12: It always seems impossible until it's done.
mainscreen-quote13: People who are crazy enough to think they can change the world, are the ones who do.
mainscreen-quote14: No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.
mainscreen-quote15: One finds limits by pushing them.
mainscreen-quote16: Every day, we choose who we are by how we define ourselves.
mainscreen-quote17: It's never too late to be what you might have been.
mainscreen-quote18: Believe you can and you're halfway there
mainscreen-quote19: Build your own dreams, or someone else will hire you to build theirs.
mainscreen-quote20: I'm not afraid of storms, for I'm learning how to sail my ship.
mainscreen-quote21: Everything you've ever wanted is on the other side of fear.
mainscreen-quote22: A problem is a chance for you to do your best.
mainscreen-quote23: If opportunity doesn't knock, build a door.
mainscreen-quote24: What you think, you become. What you feel, you attract. What you imagine, you create.
mainscreen-quote25: You must do the things you think you cannot do.
mainscreen-quote26: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted.
mainscreen-quote27: Your big opportunity may be right where you are now.
mainscreen-quote28: Everything has beauty, but not everyone can see.
mainscreen-quote29: The time is always right to do what is right.
mainscreen-quote30: Too low they build, who build beneath the stars.
mainscreen-quote31: There is no excuse to not live up to your fullest potential.
noplaystyles-desc: None of the currently loaded mods seem to offer any playstyle. Please ensure you enable the necessary mods for playstyles
setting-hover-developermode: Enables additional settings for game developers and modders. Also shows the server logs instead of the story logs on singleplayer.
setting-hover-errorreporter: Launch error reporter on startup which displays any errors that may have occurred when the server launched. Very helpful when building mods for VS.
setting-hover-extdebuginfo: Displays additional debug info in the debug screen, in the frame profiler and in item stack tooltips
setting-hover-opengldebug: Enables the OpenGL debug mode to more precisely track down such errors. Reduces game performance.
setting-hover-openglerrorchecking: Enables additional OpenGL error checking to more precisely track down such errors. Reduces game performance.
setting-hover-debugtexturedispose: Enable Texture Dispose Debugging to find memory leaks. Reduces game performance.
setting-hover-debugvaodispose: Enable VAO Dispose Debugging to find memory leaks. Reduces game performance.
setting-hover-debugsounddispose: Enable Sound Dispose Debugging to find memory leaks. Reduces game performance.
setting-hover-blockinfohud: Displays a small text box at the center-top of the screen showing you the name and description of the block or entity you are currently looking at
setting-hover-blockinteractioninfohud: Displays information on how to interact with the block or entity you are currently looking at
setting-hover-coordinatehud: Displays a small text box at the top-right corner of the screen showing you the coordinates and cardinal direction of your current position and looking direction
setting-hover-minimaphud: Displays a minimap at the top-right corner of the screen

craftinginfo-starterguide-text:
Starter Survival Guide
Survival: The Art of not dying

Disclaimer: This guide is purposely kept short, a comprehensive survival guide can be found on the wiki.

First tools
Find flint or hard stones. They can often be found loose on the ground. When you have 2 of them, shift-right-click to place one on the ground to begin knapping.

Expanding inventory
Your starting inventory has 10 slots, you can also carry up to 4 baskets or other containers. The most basic one, the hand basket, requires 10 cattails. Harvest cattails from reeds or papyrus, then hit 'E' to open your inventory to craft. The crafting recipe is on the hand basket page.

Finding food
An easy food source is berries from berry bushes. If you are feeling adventurous, attempt to hunt and kill an animal. Cooked cattail roots are a good emergency food. Keep an eye open for crops, they will be valuable food sources in the longer term. Once you found clay, be sure to get into meal cooking to greatly improve your nutrition intake.

Fire / Light
Knap a knife and use it to gather grass. Place the grass on the ground, add 4 pieces of fire wood and ignite it with a Firestarter. You can now use the firepit to cook roots and meat, or light torches that can be made from sticks and dry grass.

Combat
To hunt and kill in the stone age, craft yourself a spear or wooden club. Put together some improvised armor for some very basic protection.

Shelter
It is a good idea to build a small shelter before the night sets. Useful stone age building materials are cob, soil, packed dirt, cobble stone from ruins and logs.

Preparing for winter
On standard worlds, you have about 70 in-game days to prepare for the cold season, where you can no longer grow crops and wild animals yield less meat, and you can also suffer from the cold. It's recommended to stock up on food by preserving it and keeping animals.

For further progression, see Progression Guide.
gamemechanicinfo-foodpreservation-text:
Food preservation
Summer in a jar!

Preserving food can greatly increase its shelf life. This is particularly valuable in hot climates or during summer, as food spoils quicker in the heat, and for long winters when less food is available. There are several food preservation methods, combining them can have a multiplicative effect.

Cellars
Any fully enclosed space is considered a cellar and will have a low and consistent year-round temperature. The most simple cellar consists of a 1x2x1 hole with a container in it, that's covered up with soil. More elaborate versions can be up to 7x7x7 blocks in size with a door. To verify a cellar is working, look at any container's block info. You will want to reach the lowest possible food perish speed. Build cellar walls from soil, brick or stone materials.

Crocks
You can place meals inside crocks to receive a slight benefit, additionally you can seal crocks with wax or fat to reduce the decay rate 10-fold. A shelf placed in your cellar makes it easy to organize your crocks.

Storage vessels
A storage vessel is a good place to store grains, grain products such as bread, and raw vegetables.

Pickling
If you have access to salt, you can pickle meat and vegetables in a barrel: look up the recipes in the handbook.
gamemechanicinfo-animalhusbandry-text:
Animal Husbandry
Begin the agricultural revolution!

Bighorn sheep, boars and chickens can be turned into productive livestock. When you come across them, enclose them in a fenced-in area or chase them to your desired location. They are also attracted to troughs filled with food. Use a small trough (filled with grain) for chickens and a large trough (filled with grain or dry grass or vegetables) for boars and sheep. Feeding male and female animals will also make them produce offspring and prevent them from losing weight during winter.

Ewes can be milked to produce cheese.

Rearing poultry
Poultry (chickens) lay eggs instead of giving birth to live young. The eggs must be incubated for several days to hatch. Place a Henbox to provide your chickens with a place to lay eggs and sit on them. Also requires a rooster to fertilize them eggs! If there are not enough henboxes, chickens will lay eggs on the ground which will not hatch.

Domestication
Animals bred this way, will, over several generations, lose their fear and aggressiveness towards the player. After the 3rd generation you can also instantly kill them with a cleaver.

Beekeeping
In order to obtain wax and honey, you will need to build skeps into which wild bees like to swarm. Be sure to place some flowers around. You can move a populated skep inside a free backpack slot by right clicking it. Carry it to the desired location and use CTRL+Scroll wheel to select that backpack slot, to place the skep back down again. Your bees will visit nearby flowers and slowly produce honey, a richly populated skep can also in turn swarm to start a new bee colony in a nearby empty skep. When your skep colony is mature, break it to remove the honeycomb, note that this is quite likely to anger the bees. Angry bees can become diverted if there happens to be anything nearby which looks similar. Squeeze the honeycomb over a bucket to extract the honey, leaving wax. Honey can be taken from the bucket into individual bowls.
craftinginfo-mealcooking-text:
Meal making
Listen to the pot lid rattle

The creation of meals will allow you to subsist for longer on the food you have gathered. Create a bowl and a pot with pottery and fire them in a pit kiln. Once you have a fired pot, place it into a firepit, this will add 4 "cooking pot" slots to the firepit inventory where you can place ingredients. You can cook many different meals by filling 2 - 4 slots of the cooking pot with ingredients. All used slots must hold an equal amount of items. Add up to 6 of each item for 6 portions (takes longer to cook!)

If you actually want to eat that meal instead of inhaling the sweet aroma, you will need a bowl. Place the pot containing the cooked meal down on any surface, then with an empty bowl in hand, right-click on the pot to fill the bowl. You can then eat from the bowl.

You can create many types of meals using the recipes below. Use 1 of each ingredient in each chosen slot, to make one portion: or for 2 portions, every slot used by the recipe must hold 2x ingredients, etc

Meat Stew
First 2 slots must be raw red meat or poultry. Optional additions: 0-2 raw red meat or poultry, 0-2 vegetables, 0-2 eggs, 0-2 soybeans, 0-1 fruit or honey (0.2 L)

Vegetable Stew
First 2 slots must be vegetable. Optional additions: 0-2 vegetables, 0-2 soybeans

Note: Mushrooms are considered vegetables

Porridge
First 2 slots must be grain. Optional additions: 0-2 grain, 0-2 vegetables, 0-2 fruit, 0-1 honey (0.2 L)

Soup
First 2 slots must be 1 water and 1 vegetable. Place the water using a bucket. Optional additions: 0-1 raw red meat, raw poultry or egg, 0-2 vegetables

Scrambled eggs
First 2 slots must be eggs. Optional additions: 0-2 cheese, 0-2 vegetables

Jam
2 fruit + 2 honey (0.2L portions).

Simple meals such as roasted meat or cooked cattail root can simply be prepared over a firepit, no pot required! See also clay oven for baking bread, and Pie-making guide.
craftinginfo-progressionguide-text:
Progression Guide
The desire to learn is the basis of all human progress

Stone Age
Craft stone tools through knapping, make fire, forage for food and build a shelter. See also: Starter Survival Guide

Pottery Age
Learn and master pottery. Craft yourself clay vessels, for storage, pots and bowls, for cooking and eating meals, as well as a crucible and tool molds, to prepare for the copper age. This is also a good time to start farming.
A wood lamellar armor set (head, body, legs) provides some additional protection against low tier foes. Or gamboised armor is excellent if you have a lot of flax.

Early Copper Age
Find 40 nuggets of copper. You can find them loose on the ground (which indicates an underground deposit!), in cracked vessels, through panning sand and gravel or by purchasing them from traders. Acquire charcoal and smelt the copper on a firepit. See also: Smelting Guide

Late Copper Age
Mine enough copper deposits and create an anvil mold. Once you have cast an anvil, you will be able to create fine tools like a saw, which will let you craft wooden boards.
With boards you can, among other things, create shields, and barrels, which let you preserve vegetables and produce leather for leather armor.

Bronze Age
Acquire one of the 3 types of bronze:
- Tin bronze: Find tin ore and mix it with copper
- Bismuth bronze: Find zinc and bismuth ore, mix them with copper
- Black bronze: Find gold and silver ore, mix them with copper

Ways to find these ores:
- Tin: Underground, very rarely on the surface, from traders, rarely from cracked ore vessels or from panning.
- Zinc, bismuth: Underground, rarely from cracked ore vessels or from traders
- Gold, silver: Inside quartz deposits, but requires either bombs or a bronze pick to mine; rarely in cracked ore vessels

Use the prospecting pick, to help narrow down locations, when searching for underground ores.

Iron age
Find iron, mine iron-bearing ores and build a bloomery base and chimney from fired fire clay bricks. Make sure you have enough coal or charcoal. Place the iron ore nuggets and coal into the bloomery and then ignite it. About one in-game day later, the bloomery will stop burning and you can break it to acquire iron blooms. Iron blooms have to be worked on the anvil to create wrought iron ingots, which in turn can be worked into tools. The anvil must be bronze tier or higher.

Refining iron blooms can be mechanized with a helve hammer.

The bloomery can also be used to make glass from quartz. Glass has decorative uses, can be used to craft lanterns, and you can create greenhouses to extend the types of crops you can farm.

Late iron age
If you have encountered meteoric iron along your journey and you have a firm grip on iron working, it might be wise to construct an iron anvil through smithing, which allows you to work meteoric iron, for a roughly 20% boost in tool durability.

Steel age
Steel tools grant a hefty bonus of 2.5x the durability compared to iron, but the creation of steel is a complex and time intensive process. Head over to the steelmaking guide once you feel ready to achieve this feat.
craftinginfo-armor-text:
Armor
So you can take a hit.

Choosing the right armor is the difference between winning or losing. Low tier armor breaks quickly against high tier attacks, whereas high tier armor can become very costly - each have their up- and downsides. Here's a lineup:

Shields
The cheapest form of protection is a shield, though you will need planks (and hence a saw) in order to make one.

Improvised armor
The earliest type of armor you can make. Only protects your body while leaving your head and legs exposed. It can only take a few hits before it brakes, but nonetheless can save your life in dire times.

Lamellar armor
Somewhat more effort to due to the requirement of pelts, but offers greater protection while still relatively low cost to create. You can create lamellar armor from wood, copper or bronze.

Leather armor
Offers a good balance between flexibility and protection.

Gamboised armor
Created by layering lots of linen. Takes an immense amount of linen to create, but therefore offers great protection without losing too much flexibility.

Brigandine armor
Heavy metal armor. Great protection at the cost of reduced flexibility. You can create brigandine from copper, bronze or iron.

Chain armor
While chain is a lot of effort to smith, it's offering great protection while still being quite lightweight. You can create chain armor from copper, bronze or iron.

Scale armor
Heavy duty armor. Close to impenetrable but also costly in material and flexibility. You can create scale armor from copper, bronze or iron.

Plate armor
Turns you into a walking tank. The highest tier, steel plate armor, makes you practically invulnerable. But be sure to bring lots of food with you and don't expect to escape a battle while wearing it.
craftinginfo-knapping-text:
Knapping
Can't wait to get your hands on those handy stone age tools? Then keep on reading!

To begin knapping, you have to first collect 2 stones: either flints or hard loose stones (e.g. granite). With a stone in your active hand slot, aim at the ground and hold Sneak + Right mouse (once for flint, or twice for any other stone) to place the stone to create a knapping surface. Then select one of the recipes, for the type of stone tool you want to create. The shape of the stone tool will be shown on the knapping surface. With another stone in hand, use the left mouse button to remove all orange voxels to form the chosen stone tool shape.

Tips: To see which stones are hard enough to make tools, check the tooltip in the inventory. You can immediately knap loose stones on the ground instead of picking them up, if you have another stone in-hand and use Sneak + Right mouse. To save time, not all orange voxels need to be removed, only those directly touching the tool head. Some recipes such as stone knife blade or arrow heads create multiple items.
craftinginfo-smithing-text:
Smithing
Got your anvil ready? Time to get real.

Smithing is the way to enter the late copper age and beyond. If you don't have an anvil yet, create an anvil mold through clay forming, fire it and fill it with 900 units of copper or bronze. You will also need a hammer. Smelt some ingots to be forged. Build a forge and fill it with charcoal. Use right click to place one or two ingots into the forge and ignite with a torch in hand to heat up your ingots to a white-hot temperature. When the ingot is hot enough, take it from the forge, and place it on the anvil. You will be offered recipes, carefully select the one you want to smith. Use the hammer in different tool modes (hit 'F') to spread the metal into the voxels and remove any excess metal. Additional ingots can be added in the same way if you need more metal.

Congratulations! You are now a master smith \o/
craftinginfo-clayforming-text:
Clay forming

Hands-on sculpting. Ever wanted to feel the moist, soft clay as you squeeze it between your fingers?

Clay forming produces many pottery items and also tool molds. As with knapping, hold Sneak + Right mouse with clay in hands to create a clay forming surface. A selection of recipes will be offered. Once you have selected a recipe, you have to form it. Use the left mouse button to remove voxels and the right mouse button to add voxels. Once the shape is complete, pick it up and fire it in a pit kiln.

Tip: You can select different tool modes (hit 'F') to add/remove multiple voxels, as well as to copy whole layers of clay with the copy layer mode.
craftinginfo-smelting-text:
Smelting

Metallurgy 101. Only here on Vintage Story.

To acquire your first metal tools you will need to smelt copper, and later on bronze. You will need charcoal, clay, and copper nuggets. Craft a crucible through clay forming and fire it in a pit kiln. You can acquire charcoal through the process of charcoal burning. Before you begin, also prepare and fire one or more tool molds. You might want to start out with a pickaxe and hammer mold.

Once prepared, place the crucible in the firepit, then place nuggets into the 4 crucible slots and heat with charcoal. You can place any amount of ore nuggets in the crucible (128 per slot X 4), but the more ore you add, the longer the smelting process will take. It's more efficient if you fill the slots evenly.

Once smelted, take the crucible out of the firepit and hold over a mold, press right mouse to begin pouring. Most molds require 100 units of metal to be complete. The molten metal will be very hot initially, after the item has cooled to below 200 degrees, you can take out your cast item.

Congratulations! You are now a master metallurgist \o/

Smelting high melting point ores
Some ores, such as quartz, iron ore and meteoric iron have high melting points that cannot be reached using a simple crucible in a firepit. These you will have to smelt in a bloomery + chimney.
craftinginfo-charcoalburning-text:
Charcoal burning
Coal. Synonymous to the industrial revolution.

Charcoal is the first source of fuel used to achieve temperatures high enough to smelt metal ores. Charcoal requires a lot of firewood to produce and might require you to chop down a forest or two.

Once you think you have gathered enough firewood, dig a pit. Your charcoal pit can be any dimension up to 11x11x11 blocks, though 2x2x2 should be fine to start with. Fill your pit with complete stacks of firewood and make sure you leave no empty blocks, or your firewood will burn to ash. Cover the filled pit completely, but leave a single block in the center exposed to air.

Using dried grass and 4 more firewood, build a firepit on the center exposed block and light it. Quickly (you have 30 in-game minutes) cover it up with solid blocks to seal the pit. If the pit begins smoking peacefully, you will be rewarded with charcoal in less than an in-game day! If you hear burning sounds, you should open up the pit and quickly extinguish the fire - you must have missed a spot and the pit was not airtight.
craftinginfo-cokeoven-text:
Coke oven
Coke is to coal what charcoal is to wood. Coke is produced by 'burning' coal in an oxygen-less environment, such as a coke oven.

A coke oven is a multi-block structure, made of fire clay bricks or any type of refractory bricks, and an iron coke oven door. The oven is essentially a 3x3x3 cube of refractory bricks, with the center empty, and one of the four cardinal directions from the center also empty. In the center you place the coal layers, and in the adjacent empty space, the coke oven door. Ignite the coal with a torch and close the door - in 12 hours it will be converted to coke. Coke burns at very high temperatures, though not for as long as raw coal.
craftinginfo-cheese-text:
Cheese Making
Making cheese is a lengthy but rewarding process, that can be broken down into four steps:

Step 1: Fill a barrel with either 25 or 50 liters of milk, and add pickled vegetables of any sort. Seal the barrel, and in time the milk will curdle.

Step 2: Add salt to the curdled milk and seal the barrel. In time this will create cottage cheese (You can use a bowl to eat the cottage cheese).

Step 3: Use a piece of linen to remove the cottage cheese from the barrel. Place the bundle on the ground, and add a stick. Twist the curd bundle until all the whey is removed. Open the curd bundle, and add 5 salt to the exposed cheese wheel.

Step 4: At this point you can either place the salted raw cheese wheel on a shelf to cure, or craft it in your grid with a piece of wax to turn it into a w raw cheese wheel, which will last longer. Place the salted/waxed cheese wheel on a shelf to cure. After many days, you will have cheddar cheese!

Blue Cheese: To make blue cheese, you must store the raw cheese in a cellar with a very low light level, but yet the cellar must have at least one block open to the outside.
gamemechanicinfo-prospecting-text:
Prospecting
Ready to move on from the copper age?

In order to advance you will have to find some rather rare resources to create bronze. The prospecting pick can help you find where not to search for them. Once you have either poured or smithed a prospecting pick, pack your bags and go for a journey!

Density Search Mode
Break 3 rock blocks in 'close' proximity to "sample" the area for ores. The sampled blocks must be located a minimum of 3 blocks apart and a maximum of 16 blocks apart. You can sample anywhere, as long as you break rock. For example, when you come across a cave, an outcropping of stone, or dig through the dirt to reach solid rock, break one block to start the sampling process. Move at least three blocks and break another block. Do this again to finish collecting your samples.

Once your samples are completed, the chat info log will show you a reading of all prospectable resources at this location. Results are shown as ore densities. A low density resource means you probably want to move on and keep prospecting until you find a medium to high density location, it might also mean you are near the edge of a deposit, so look around to see if you can find a stronger reading. Even a high density reading is no certainty to actually find ore in that exact spot, though it must be nearby. It is up to you how you then locate the individual ore veins underground which the prospecting process has detected.

Node Search Mode
If the server or game settings allow it, the prospecting pick can instead be set to 'Node Search' mode using the 'F' (tool mode) key with the Propick in hands. In this mode the prospecting pick will probe at a much smaller radius (2 - 8 blocks, configurable through a command), and if it finds something, there is guaranted to be an ore vein within the vicinity. In that case it is only a matter of finding the right direction to mine towards...
gamemechanicinfo-mechanicalpower-text:
Mechanical Power
The mechanical work horse is the path to prosperity.

Mechanical power can currently be used to mechanize milling, to automate working iron blooms or smithing any type of metal plate, and to power the Archimedes screw for transporting items. You will need to craft one windmill rotor, at least 4 sails as well as a few axles and gears. The windmill requires at least 5 blocks of vertical space and usually gets more wind the higher it is, so begin by placing the rotor on a tower or the side of a tall building. The back of the windmill rotor will be attached to axles and gears to bring power to your machine.

For mechanized milling: Craft a quern from any igneous rock, then use axles and gears to connect the rotor to either the top or bottom of the quern to be automated. If the quern's output slot is full or occupied, the quern will begin to drop items on each of its 4 sides. Placing a block beside the quern will prevent the quern from dropping items on the blocked side, but reduces the grinding efficiency. You can use this fact to place hoppers and chests below the sides of the quern to catch quern output. Placing one hopper above the quern allows you to grind multiple stacks of material automatically.

For mechanized smithing: Smith or cast a helve hammer head, the helve hammer itself, a base and a wooden toggle. Using the gears and axles connect the output of your windmill rotor to the left or right side of the wooden toggle. Place the helve hammer base adjacent to the toggle. Place an anvil (it must be bronze tier or higher) three blocks away from the base and then attach the helve hammer onto the base. If you add an optional brake it must be placed on the free side of the helve hammer base (opposite the axle bringing in power).

To power the machine you have built: Right click on the windmill rotor to add the sails. Each set of 4 sails will add 20% power output to the windmill. When there is enough wind, the windmill will turn and the machine will begin to move. A windmill with more sails will begin turning at lower wind speeds, as a certain amount of power is needed to get the quern and helve hammers moving.

Larger and more complex builds can be created using the large wooden gear. Combined with standard gears it can either speed up rotation (but with weaker torque) or slow down rotation (but with much stronger torque). It can also bring together torque from several windmills or other power sources. Optionally, you can use a transmission with a clutch next to it, to temporarily interrupt a power train. A brake can stop a power train completely.
gamemechanicinfo-temporalstability-text:
Temporal Stability
The world is in a constant state of flux.

The cyan gear between your health and hunger bar is your temporal stability meter. Staying in areas of low stability will drain your temporal stability, which is indicated by your gear turning counter-clockwise. If your temporal stability reaches zero, you will enter the rust world, where tough enemies are more likely to spawn and you will take constant damage. Certain areas, especially deep underground are temporally unstable. If your temporal stability is dropping when on the surface, you might want to find another place to settle down. Sometimes you will encounter temporal storms on the surface, which have the same effect as having low temporal stability. When a temporal storm is approaching, the chat box will let you know, so you have time to prepare.

Ways to increase your temporal stability:
- Enter a temporally stable area, which is indicated by your gear turning clockwise
- Killing drifters will recover small amounts of temporal stability
- Putting a temporal gear in your left hand, a knife in your main hand and holding right mouse will transfer temporal stability from the gear to you, but consumes the gear and some of your health.

Rifts
Rifts are portals to the rust world that appear at random on the surface, which spawn drifters and cause your temporal stability to drop greatly when up close. They disappear on their own after 1 or 2 ingame days. The amount of appearing rifts depend on the current global rift activity. Torch light currently deters rift apperances, in case you want to make your base more rift-proof.
gamemechanicinfo-weather-text:
Weather
Not only looks pretty, it also does stuff.

Weather in Vintage Story is location based, so you will experience more rain in Jungles and less in Deserts. As of version 1.12, rain and snow will have the following effects on the game world:
- Make your farmland moist so crops can grow.
- Extinguishes firepits, torches and forges
- Cools down any hot work items on forges and anvils.

Blocks extinguished by rainfall can be relit using a torch.
gamemechanicinfo-stonelayers-text:
There are three general types of stone in Vintage Story:

Sedimentary stone types include Claystone, Sandstone, Limestone, Chalk, Shale, Chert, Conglomerate, and Bauxite.
Sedimentary layers will always occur above igneous and metamorphic stone layers (except basalt, which is an exception). So for instance if you are searching for limestone or chalk, and you see the top stone layer of an area is igneous or metamorphic, then look elsewhere - there will not be sedimentary below. However if the top layer is another sedimentary stone, it is possible that different sedimentary layers are below - perhaps find a cave and investigate deeper.

Metamorphic stone types include Phyllite and Slate, as well as marble. Marble however only occurs as deposits within Phyllite or Slate. Metamorphic layers will always occur below sedimentary layers, but above igneous layers.

Igneous stone types include Andesite, Granite, Peridotite, and Basalt. Igneous layers always occur below sedimentary and metamorphic layers (except basalt, which is an exception and can occur above ANY other stone layer). If the top layer of stone in an area is igneous (other than basalt) then you know that there are no sedimentary or metamorphic layers below.

Searching for limestone or chalk? They are not any more or less likely to occur based on climate or any other factor, but are simply random. Just be sure to pay attention to the top stone layer, and if it is sedimentary or basalt, you might want to investigate caves in the area to make sure there is not more sedimentary layers below.

Searching for bauxite? Bauxite, like all stone layers, is not linked to any particular geography or climate. Explore and you should eventually find it! Being sedimentary, it will always be above metamorphic and igneous layers (except basalt).
gamemechanicinfo-panning-title: Game Mechanic: Panning for ore and more
gamemechanicinfo-panning-text:
Panning
There's gold in those hills!

Panning allows the player to obtain small quantities of copper and a few other types of nuggets, as well as other items. It is a useful way to obtain copper nuggets in the early game, if you're not finding enough through exploring.

All the player needs for panning are a wooden pan, water to stand in, and either sand, gravel, or bony soil (muddy gravel will NOT work). Simply stand in the water, right click the pan on the material to be sifted, and then right click once to start sifting. Each block of material has eight 'charges' for the pan. Make sure the block of material is not touching water or it will be washed away as soon as the first layer is removed.

The stone type of sand and gravel makes no difference in results, aside form the stones that you obtain from it. Sand and gravel produce the same results. Bony soil, however, will produce a much different set of results from sand and gravel.
gamemechanicinfo-farming-text:
When you've found several seeds, and found a place to settle down, it's time to start farming. There are several factors that play into farming:

Soil Fertility
Soil comes in four levels of fertility; low, medium, high, and 'terra preta'. Try to avoid planting crops in low fertility soil. They may struggle to mature in a timely manner.

Moisture
Crops need moisture to grow. Planting crops within three blocks of water will help them maintain good moisture levels. However, you can grow crops even on ground with no water nearby by using a watering can, or natural rainfall, which will increase soil moisture.

Planting:
Once you've selected your location to farm, till the soil using a hoe, and plant your seeds by right clicking. You should also think about the temperature and nutrient requirements of the seeds.

Soil Nutrients
The tool tip of the tilled farmland will tell you the status of the three soil nutrients (N, P, and K) for that block. Different plants need different nutrients, and will use them up from the soil as they grow. If the required nutrient is low, they will grow much slower. It is good practice to rotate your crops so that each subsequent planting uses a different nutrient than the one before. Farmland will naturally regenerate nutrients over time when left fallow. There are also several types of fertilizer in the world, which can more quickly replenish nutrients.

Temperature damage
Different crops have different tolerances for extreme temperature - both low and high. If a crop is subjected to excessive heat or cold, it may become frost or heat damaged, which will cause it to only give half the yield when you harvest. In extreme temperatures, crops will start to take cold/heat damage, accumulating damage points. The points will go away if the temperature returns to safer levels, however, if the crop accumulates 48 hours of extreme temperature damage, it will die. Dead crops will give a seed (but no other produce) at harvest, unless they died very young, in which case they may yield nothing at all.

Harvesting
Once mature, harvest crops by hand, or with a scythe.

Pests
Certain animals, such as hares, will attempt to eat your crops. It's wise to protect them with a rough-hewn fence or other obstacle.
gamemechanicinfo-fruittrees-text:
Where to Find
Fruit trees can be found throughout the world, in virtually all climates. Different climates will have different types of trees. Not all fruit trees can survive in all climates.

Growth Habits
Fruit trees start small, but over a long time period will get very large, bit by bit; they do not instantly grow to maturity like regular trees.
They only bear fruit once a year, and this time will vary by the type. They will go through stages of flowering, fruit bearing, and fruit ripening. Trees of temperate climates will go through a dormancy period where they have no leaves.

Propogation
You can propograte fruit trees by removing a branch to get a cutting, and then planting the cutting on dirt, or placing the cutting onto the cut branch stub of another fruit tree. Only a portion of planted cuttings will succeed, and an even smaller number of grafts.
craftinginfo-alcohol-title: Crafting Mechanic: Brewing and Distilling Alcohol
craftinginfo-alcohol-text:
Fermenting
The initial step of making alcohol is to ferment your raw material in a barrel. You can ferment fruit juices (which will require a fruit press), honey, and flour (which will require a quern) with water. The result will be a cider, wine, ale, or mead, depending on the raw material used.

Distilling
The next step of alcohol making is distilling. For this you will need a boiler and a condenser. The boiler can only be fueled with firewood. Place a bucket under the condenser spout, fill the condenser with water, and build a firepit under the boiler. Fill the boiler with up to 30L of fermented alcohol, and light the fire under the boiler. After a time, the fermented alcohol will be converted to a distilled spirit, such as brandy, whiskey, or vodka.

Aqua Vitae
Repeat the distilling process once more, but with spirits rather than fermented alcohol. The product of this will be nearly pure alcohol, called Aqua Vitae, which can be used as an ingredient for useful items.
craftinginfo-pie-text:
Piemaking

Pies require a clay oven to bake them in. You must also have a table on which to form your pies.

With 2 or more dough in hand, right-click to place the dough on the table, which will create the piecrust base. Fill it with four filling items. You cannot mix food groups, but you can mix different types of food within a group (different berries, for instance). After adding the filling, you have the option to use two more dough to add a top: right-click again with dough to change the pattern of the top.

With an empty hand, right click the pie to pick it up, and then place it in the clay oven to bake.

After it has finished baking you can place it back down on a table, and use a knife to cut it into quarters to eat. One quarter of a pie is similar to a meal in a bowl, your character will not eat all of it if already sated.

Survival mode: Limited blocks, limited health, cannot fly

Passive: Creatures only attack when provoked.

handbooktext-henbox:
Place henbox down in a spot your hens have access to. The hens will lay eggs in a henbox by preference, not on the ground. Once the henbox has 3 eggs, a broody hen will sit incubating those eggs until they hatch.

For viable eggs, hens must have access to a rooster! Hens must be well fed to lay! A broody hen needs to have a full belly before it will sit for a day!

If every henbox is occupied, hens wanting to lay may lay eggs on the ground, which can then be picked up. The player can also collect eggs from a henbox, by right-clicking.

itemdesc-armor-legs-antique-forlorn-pris: The romance of chivalry gave way to new zealotry; they kept their spurs nonetheless.
